content.statement: Category theory was developed in the 1940s by Samuel Eilenberg and Saunders Mac Lane as a formal language for describing mathematical structures and their relationships.

explanation.intuition: Category theory emerged from algebraic topology to provide a unified framework for understanding mathematical structures. Rather than focusing on what objects are made of, it focuses on how they relate to each other through morphisms.
explanation.key_insight: Category theory abstracts away from the internal structure of mathematical objects, focusing instead on the relationships (morphisms) between them and how these relationships compose.
explanation.technical_details: Eilenberg and Mac Lane introduced categories in their 1945 paper 'General Theory of Natural Equivalences' to formalize the concept of natural transformation in algebraic topology. The framework proved so powerful it became a universal language for mathematics.

historical_context.original_motivation: Formalizing natural transformations in algebraic topology
historical_context.evolution: From algebraic topology to logic, computer science, physics, and beyond

sources.citation: Eilenberg, S., & Mac Lane, S. (1945). General theory of natural equivalences. Transactions of the American Mathematical Society, 58(2), 231-294.
Mac Lane, S. (1971). Categories for the Working Mathematician. Springer.

applications.context: Category theory provides the theoretical foundation for functional programming, including composition, functors, and monads
Type theory uses categorical semantics, especially cartesian closed categories
